author: Emily
title: Amazing
content: I love the way Lemony Snicket uses intelligent words and different settings and themes for writing this series. I love it.

author: A. Luciano
title: Dark and Hysterically Funny
content:
This book begins the story of the three Baudelaire children.  Violet is fourteen, Klaus is twelve, and Sunny is a baby.  The author starts off by telling you that the story will not be a happy one, and he is certainly right.  The children first learn that both of their parents have died in a fire.  From there things get worse.  Their mansion is gone, leaving the children homeless as well as orphans.  Their parents' will stated that they should go to a relative living somewhere in the city, so their lives won't be disrupted too much.  After some searching, the executor of the will finds a relative--Count Olaf, who lives on the other side of the city.

Count Olaf is a mean and scary man, who makes the children do hard work for him all day and only gives a small room with one bed for all of them to live in.  The children are miserable living with him right from the start.  Then things get worse still.  Count Olaf is determined to get his hands on the Baudelaire fortune, which Violet will inherit when she turns eighteen.  The children know that when he asks them to perform in a play with him, he is up to something.  Will they be able to figure out what it is in time to stop him from getting all of their money?

I love the tone of this book.  I love how the author keeps talking directly to the reader to point out that he is telling the story.  Instead of being an impersonal voice, he is another character, with a distinctive personality.

The children in this story are incredibly strong.  They have lived through awful situations but they are still able to function and depend on each other, so despite the author's warnings, you never really believe they are in such trouble.

author: RaptorTBF
title: What a strange idea.
content:
Reverse psychology in its most freakish form.
From the start of any of Lemony Snicket's books, on the back of his books, and throughout the pages, Snicket urges readers to put down the book and for the reader to pick up something happier. Who would have thought that a children's author would successfully convince children to keep reading his books by making his stories everything that kids, stereotypically, don't want to read.
Spread like encyclopedic lice throughout his books are helpful explanations as to what some of the larger words he uses in his story mean. Soon our children will be using words that we aren't even sure as to what the meanings of them are.
All in all Snicket's stories aren't really all the groundbreaking but are a delight to read simply for the author's commentary into the lives of the unfortunate Baudelaire children, and occasionally references to the author's own life.
I strongly recommend these books for anyone who enjoys Roald Dahl's style of writing, both in his children's stories and his more adult short stories. Snicket grabs your attention and squeezes it until a passerby could easily mistaken it for an Italian zucchini.
An instant classic for anyone who enjoys reading about other peoples woes.

author: A animal lover

author: LoveJoyPeace
title: Child's review.
content: This book is the first in a series of thirteen and is about three orphans who are left a great fortune by their parents.  Unfortunately, they must live with a count whose mind is set on taking their fortune from them.  I like this book a lot because the author is very much talking to you and makes you feel as though you are in the story.  His explanation of tricky words is also helpful.  There is a lot of suspense and sad occasions.  I would recommend this series only to people who can handle the constant sadness.  Even though I wanted to stop reading, I couldn't because it is such a great story.

author: An 11-year old reader

content: When three childrens parents die in a fire at their big manshion, the children must stay with blustering Count Olaf who seems nice at first, but beware!, because Count Olaf is a greedy sicspisios man that is a old fool with a big brain trying hard to get the poor orphans forchain.

author: Joshua A. Patterson
title: don't read it and it will be unfortunate for you!
content:
I've read several reviews knocking this book. So, here is an opinion from a 5th grade teacher who reads this book to her class every year.

First of all: it is NOT Harry Potter, nor is this novel trying to be. Yes, the books are dark. But, to those who say they are inappropriate for kids, look in the news. Most children don't live a sunny, happy existence. Kids who have tough lives can relate to this novel and it will not do any damage to kids who come from happy homes.

Second of all, I feel the novels are fantastically written for a 4th/5th grade level. Snickett does explain word definitions. This is not dumbing down since the one thing most kids struggle with is reading comprehension. If they can't understand it, you won't enjoy it.

Lastly, this is one of the only books that I read aloud that my class shows any interest in. They laugh at Count Olaf, they gasp when he slaps Klaus. If The Bad Beginning grabs children's interest and causes them to read the whole series, think of how much the kids are reading. The only way to be a better reader is to read!

I would thoroughly recommend this book.

author: Trackspider
title: The Bad Beginning- Great start to a great series.

And it actually has a better plotline than alot of popular books out there, for example, Percy Jackson, ugh, that series is so freaking terrible that it made some people betray there religion and become a fairytale greek god worshipper. Thats just messed up. I dont think this book tops Harry Potter but its on Harry Potters level. Great Book.

author: Sylviastel
title: Such an Easy Entertaining Read!
content:
Lemony Snicket's book, "The Bad Beginning," is the story about the Baudelaire orphans (Klaus, 14 year old Violet, and baby Sunny) who are forced to live with a distant cousin, Count Olaf, a struggling actor, in his terrible home environment.

The author does a very good job in moving the story quickly along to allow the suspense to begin. Count Olaf is a terrible man, the children learn but he's a relative. He has a vicious, evil plan to inherit the Baudelaire fortune.

Without giving it away, the good and bad people are easy to learn in this story. The characters are colorful like Count Olaf, Judge Strauss, and Mr. Poe. The kids are also well-written to help move the story along.

The book only took me less than an hour to read at the most. It's an easy fun read even for adults.

author: Reggie
title: Great book
content: THIS IS ONE OF THE BEST BOOKS I HAVE EVER READ.THE BOOK KEEPS YOU GLUED TO THE PAGES. I STAYED UP LATE TO FIND OUT WHAT HAPPEND TO THE BAUDELAIRE ORPHANS.

author: Amazon Customer

author: Gale G. Gortney

title: Unfortunate is the mis-understanding of the bad reviews
content: What a book!  Snicket is amazing.  I cannot believe the bad reviews that this book has been given by other readers.  Obviously they are not capable of handling sarcastic humor. author: Italo Perazzoli
title: So Real
content:
Reading "A Series of Unfortunate Events: The Bad Beginning" I found a correlation to "Once" written by Morris Gleitzman.

The main argument of these novels are the suffering of child in a society affected by thirsty of power and individualism, which is masterfully described by Gleitzman

"You know how" against the more descriptive and less confidential described by Lemony Snicket i.e.

"Unless you have been very, very lucky, you have undoubtedly experienced events in your life that have made you cry. So unless you have been very, very lucky, you know that a good, long session of weeping can often make you feel better, even if your circumstances have not changed one bit. So it was with the Baudelair orphans"  (A Series of Unfortunate Events, Lemoy Snicket, page 57)

The plot of A series of unfortunate events is quite different here the main characters are: Violet, Klaus and Sunny Baudelaire due to a domestic accident they have lost their parents the beginning of their unhuman suffering summarised in the first paragraph and in particular Violet,  the future heir of a considerable sum of money.

For Klaus reading is a fundamental step for the developing of the society if you read carefully you will be able to resolve any kind of difficulties and problems and even the reader is involved:

"There are many, many types of books in the world, which makes good sense, because there are many, many types of people, and everybody wants to read something different. For instance, people who hate stories in which terrible things happen to small children put this book down immediately" (A Series of Unfortunate Events, Lemoy Snicket, page 83)

Philosophically speaking I think that there is a battle between the innocent world represented by Violet, Klaus and Sunny Baudelaire and the adult world inhabited by Mr. Poe and his dirty house (like his soul), Count Olaf (the devil) the winner will be described at the end.

author: tvtv3
title: And So the Story Begins.
content:
Dear Reader,

THE BAD BEGINNING is the first of a series of books entitled "A Series of Unfortunate Events."  The author, Lemony Snicket (whose real name is Daniel Handler) warns the reader several times: on the back cover of the book, in the opening section of the book, and several times throughout the book; that the book is "extremely unpleasant" and if you like nice, fluffy, happy stories that you should put the book down and read something else.

THE BAD BEGINNING briefly explains how the three Baudelaire children-Violet, Klaus, and Sunny-became orphans, how the first met their evil relative Count Olaf, Count Olaf's first scheme at stealing their money, and how they moved from one series of unfortunate events to another.

THE BAD BEGINNING is not the typical "children's book." In fact, if a child hasn't been exposed to much classical literature, fairy tales, or life experiences, they probably shouldn't be reading the book at all because it might frighten them by exposing them to all the nastiness in the world.  However, if a child has read any classical literature or fairy tales (where there is all kinds of violence and bad things going on) or has had a lot of life experiences (my grandfather died when I was in the 3rd grade) then they might actually enjoy reading THE BAD BEGINNING.

Mr. Snicket has a delightful time with language and a child's vocabulary is sure to increase after having read THE BAD BEGINNING. They also might learn a thing or two (though they might not be able to understand what they learn) about law and justice.  They are sure to find themselves saddened by the unfortunate state of the Baudelaire siblings, yet somewhat uplifted by knowing that as troublesome as their lives might be, the Baudelaire orphans have it much worse.

Still, children probably shouldn't be reading THE BAD BEGINNING at all. It's a book that youth in their teens and young adults would probably enjoy and benefit from reading the most. Unfortunately people that age are often ashamed of reading and fear of their lives becoming unfortunate by reading such a book like THE BAD BEGINNING will probably prevent them from learning the lessons found therein. Such a shame. I hope the Baudelaire children find happiness sometime.

Sincerely,

Uncle TV

author: James Martin
title: Review from Maryland
content: The Bad Beginning - Book 1 of A Series of Unfortunate EventsThis book was a fantastic fantsy especially coming from somone who does not love reading. As I read, I was waiting for the next bad thing to happen as I could visualize every page in my mind because his words were very animated. author: James Duckett
title: A fun and original read for children--and the children in us
content:
As an adult, I picked these books up to see if these would be a good book for my child to read.  And for a elementary children, this is a wonderful book.  The read is relatively quick so they aren't overwhelmed by the thickness and it is still a fun story with characters that you feel terribly bad for.

The prose is perfect for children.  It is easy to read and filled with alliteration.  Best of all, this book goes out of its way to teach vocabulary to children.  Instead of filling the book with long words (for children) expecting the children to look up the words they didn't understand (which they won't), it goes out of its way to explain the bigger words.

This is the story of the Baudelaire siblings and begins right after the death of their parents.  Orphaned, the children are placed into the care of a distant relative named Count Olaf.  It doesn't take long for the children to realize that Count Olaf does not care for the children but only in the fortune that Violet, the eldest of the three children, is set to inherit.  Soon, a scheme is hatched by Count Olaf to take control of the fortune and the only thing that can help the Baudelaire orphans is their wit, wisdom, and bravery.

You are warned at the beginning of the book, and throughout, that this book does not have a happy ending.  It is part right.  The book does not have the best ending, but it doesn't have the worst ending either.  I'll pick up the other books, but it does appear that this book will not leave you hanging and wishing for a different ending.  Actually, I prefer this ending which shows that not everything will go your way which is the norm in life and not the exception.  I don't think elementary school aged children are too young to start learning this, if they haven't already.

If you have young children (grades 2-6) I would highly recommend you encourage them to read this series.  This would be a good step into getting them to like reading.  Harry Potter, while it is a fantastic read, should be left to those who are slightly older and/or better readers than who this book is targetted towards.

author: Patrick Smadbeck
title: Corrupt Reviews!
content:
As any person who notices these kind of things, you have to consider that most of these book reviews are written by adults.
Now I forgot. This IS a children's book, right? I happen to be a fourteen years old, and I recieved this book for Christmas (from a book magazine that sold "great" books). Any person I met who read it liked the books (even my english teacher NOTE: TEACHER).
I am an avid reader, reading many of the classics (Grapes of Wrath; Hobbit; The Jungle; To Kill a Mockingbird), and enjoy the fantasy genre. So don't get me wrong by thinking I liked the book because they dumbed it down, or I'm a know-nothing (I happen to be in a special english, and math class).
I found this book to be inventive, with a new style of writing. He kept you interested with the constant mystery, and clueless adults who frusterate you until you have to laugh at them. He keeps you attentive and not bored with a change of writing every few chapters. For example, he with will have little definitions that will obviously not be real, but attached to the storyline, and little humerous tidbits like five pages of "never"'s, or a couple of pages of black. It's a refreshing edition to the many styles of writing that are used way too often, and changed the direction of "oh, the hero has trouble, he goes and meets the bad guy, and defeats him. Happily Ever After!" There is no "Happily Ever After" here, and I find that in itself funny.
If you can't handle the heat, get out of the kitchen! This was a fabulous book, and I recomend them all to anybody! I gave the book what it deserved, and if you don't like it. TOUGH! If you have nothing good to say, say nothing at all. Don't try to get people to avoid a book based on your opinion! They should avoid it on their opinion!
I bid you farewell.

author: Atheen
title: Delightful story
content:
I had a hard time getting into this book, although the title of the series  intrigued me enough to try it again and I have to admit to a certain captivation.  The series is almost like a cliff-hanger movie, with the characters facing an impossible and unpleasant predicament which they resolve only to find themselves faced with an uncertain future.
A Bad Beginning introduces the readers to the central characters, the three Baudelaire orphans Violet, Klaus and Sunny.  They are utterly charming and seem designed against stereotype.  Violet, unlike the stereotype for girls, is mathematically and mechanically inclined; she's the inventor of the three.  Klaus, unlike the stereotype for boys, is a great reader; he can learn anything from books and becomes a problem solver.  Sunny, well she's just Sunny, an adorable infant given to bitting things.
While the author goes to great lengths to inform the reader that the orphans have a hard time of it, the actual tale is not particularly upsetting or threatening.  Like Harry Potter, the Baudelaire children have lost their parents and are raised by family that is not necessarily pleasant.  In the latter case this is the mysterious, threatening, greedy Count Olaf.  While the book makes an effort to point out that not all of life goes smoothly, that it really is sometimes a series of unfortunate events, it emphasizes that these are problems to be solved, things from which we learn.  It also teaches that resources are available for problem solving, things like books, reliable adults, even siblings.
Also like the Potter series, The Series of Unfortunate Events exhibits enough plot structure, complex vocabulary, and sophisticated wit to appeal to adults as well as children.
One of the things I particularly like about the book is that the author provides a number of words and idiomatic expressions the meanings of which are explained partially by context and partially by outright definition.  He neither avoids using advanced vocabulary nor assumes that the reader will always figure out the words alone.  He acts as a teacher/parent who helps the learning process along.
A vary charming book.  I look forward to reading some of the others.

author: MagnoliaSouth
title: Cute, funny, and just plain fun.
content: I used the book as a read-aloud to my kids of 12 and 10. Lemony Snicket knows how to write. The first thing we noticed was the humorous way Lemony builds your vocabulary -- a word here which means "understanding the meaning of words". The story flows at a good pace not boring readers for a moment. The characters are colorful and well defined. The books isn't long and the writing is good for readers of 4th grade (and possibly 3rd grade) and up. While the story is truly unfortunate, it's very humorous. Thus, children shouldn't find it frightening or worrisome. The situation the children find themselves in shouldn't concern kids as it is just so outrageous. There are good plot twists and a moral lesson to be learned. It's just a darn good book.

author: Anne Meiman
title: BRILLIANT!!!
content:
I am a thirteen-year-old girl. I first read these when I was maybe 10 or 11. And let me be the first to say, I ADORE THIS BOOK! The writing style is humorous, the characters (particularly the Baudelaires) are well-written and the heroes of the story are excellent role models (epecially Violet and Klaus, who show the benefits of being interested in literature and science, and also demonstrate that there is always hope, even when it seems like the world is against you).

However, I have one small warning: the plot is geared toward older children and has some rather dark themes (parental loss, abuse, marrying an underage girl). This book may be more suited for older children, or even some adults who like YA books. I, personally, didn't really get into them until last year when I could better grasp the concepts and ideas expressed in this novel. However, I recommended this series to my eight-year-old stepsister (a lover of Tim Burton films and the like), and she seems to cherish this book as much as I do. So, maybe, just don't give them to sensitive children or people who don't enjoy darker material? You be the judge of what you/your child can handle.

Overall, however, A Series Of Unfortunate Events is a wonderful book series and I would recommend them to anyone wh cann handle them.

author: Steven Scott
title: The beginning of a terrible “friendship”
content:
Hopefully, you heeded Lemony Snicket’s wise words and dropped The Bad Beginning like a hot potato (a phrase here which means ran away from it as if it could literally burn or otherwise cause you physical harm) as soon as Mr. Poe captured Count Olaf. If so, there is nothing more to see here.

If you failed to heed the wise words of Lemony Snicket, then you’ve finished reading The Bad Beginning and are likely weeping or howling uncontrollably at the injustice of a villain such as Count Olaf escaping. I would advise you not to read further to avoid a summation, a word here which means reliving the horrible tale you were warned not to read once already, but if you didn’t heed Mr. Snicket’s warning, how likely are you to heed mine? After all, how unfair is it that three bright and kind children such as the Baudelaires should lose their parents in a terrible fire? How awful is it that they are forced to wear terrible clothing? Or adopted by a terrible man who is only interested in the fortune their parents left behind and willing to do anything to gain it?

I would like to tell you read The Bad Beginning because the Baudelaire children are kind, smart and likeable but those same qualities are what make it so difficult to recommend this book. In the end, the only recommendation I can give is this: read at your own risk...and stop while you’re ahead because it only gets worse for the Baudelaires from here.

title: This Book Was A Gas...
content: In this context "gas" meaning a great time.  While Iwas searching, one of the thngs they said they were excited about coming out was the seventh book in the "Unfortunate Events" series.After just finishing the first I can see why. I desperately want to start the second, to see what unlucky fate next befalls the three Baudelaire siblings, Violet, Klaus, and Sunny. Three very unlucky children whose parents die tragically and are forced to live with a distant relative named Count Olaf. Imagine Harry Potter never getting the chance to escape from the Dursley's and you'll get the general idea. The author relates their tale of woe with hilarity, including a technique of providing definitions for words that the reader might not be familiar with. Destined to become cult classics and handsomely designed and illustrated in their little hardback form, they're books you're kids/niece/nephew/little sibling will want all of. And you'll be sneaking them away to see what all the fuss is about.

author: Gregory S. Giovanni
title: Clever Children Only!
content:
This Series is nothing short of brilliant.  However, not for every child.  Clever kids, smart children, quiet 'outsider' types and those who like to defie thier parents should definitely read this one.  It's one of the few books that is better for boys than for gilrs!  Average kids and simple adults just won't get it.
  What we have here is Gothic for children (I refer to "Gothic revival" as outlined by Richard Davenport-Hines in his book "Gothic- -Four hundred years of excess, horror, evil, and ruin") The literary merit of these books is beyond question.  There are hundreds of linguistic jokes ("to snick" means to wound; Mr Poe works for "Mulcturary Money Management" --- go head, look up 'mulct')  The author includes himself as a charater.  In each book we find out a little more about what happened to him and his Beatrice ("Dearest, darling, dead.")
As for the concern about the 'incest' mentioned in the review below, I understand this to be a lack of knowlage concerning classic lit. - the evil uncle coniving to marry his pretty niece is stock story line from Plautus, the Mid-evil stage, all the way to Molaire and 19th C. melodrama.
Finally, the books are handsome to hold a wonderfully illustrated- -making them fun to own.
Make no mistake; horrible, awful and very sad things happen to the Baudelaire children but that is all the more reason they are perfect heroes for the 10-14 year old set.

author: Erwin Tan
title: A Hopeful Review?
content:
The Bad Beginning by Lemony Snicket is a very influential book and has had an impact on my life. It was one of the first books I was reading while I was maturing as a reader.

The book shows that life isn't always fair, but also that perseverance and never giving up is important and things may work out in the end. Things won't happen if you don't take the initiative. It also depicts that there are people with good and bad intentions within the world. There is a potential within us to do good or bad, the decision is left up to us and we must live with whatever happens, the consequences. The author's style revolves around the use of formal language as well as explaining words and phrases that adds to understanding and the mood of the story. Figurative language such as similes, metaphors, and clichés are also exercised in the book.

The book is aimed at a young audience. I would highly recommend this gem of a novel.

author: Peter
title: Awesome first book to the series. I'm hooked!
content: I wish some of the lower-star reviewers would stop analyzing this series so much and stop complaining about the violence and how bad all the adults in the story are. First of all, in some books written for children, many times some of the adult characters are written as either really stupid or else very mean or evil. The Harry Potter books are a prime example.  Both the Harry Potter series and the Lemony Snickett series are tales of good versus evil. Oftentimes there is an exaggeration of the bad characters. It just makes for a more interesting story.  I found The Bad Beginning to be fascinating and captivating from the first chapter. I can't wait to read the next book and all the ones after that. I'm hooked on the series and will be seeing the movie for sure.  I'm glad this is yet another series of books that will lure in kids of all ages, and like the Harry Potter books, will instill  young readers with an interest in reading.I liked how the Lemony Snicket books are short and very fast-paced. There was not a boring moment in the book. Wish i could say the same for Harry Potter And The Goblet Of Fire, which i found tedious as hell to read.  I read  the whole first Lemony book in under a few hours and i liked the author's literary style and his technique of explaining the meaning of some of the vocabulary words as the story goes along. This alone, will increase a young-person's vocabulary. Though they may not use those particular words in everyday conversation, when they see them again in print sometime in the future, they will know the meanings. I think this series of books will be as popular as Harry Potter, and in some ways even more so. Highly recommended. As for the  violence in the book, some of it may be a bit scary for very young children under 9, but any child who has watched today's tv shows won't be bothered by what happens in the story. If anything, it just heightens the events and makes it all more fascinating and fun. And anyway, if you're bothered with your kids reading this series, there IS a warning from Lemony Snicket himself that this story is not happy at all and doesn't have a happy ending.

In this book, there is an enormous amount of suspense and you don't have to wait until the end of the book the get into it! I loved this first book, and I am 15 years old. This set of books is one that all ages can read. Each book carries onto the next! I won't ruin the story, so go out and find this extremly great and outstanding book!

author: D. Hern
title: Dry wit, dark humor.
content:
If you like dry wit, wordplay, and dark humor, this is your book.  The basic plot is not terribly original: Orphans forced to live with a mean relative who is only interested in their money.  It's the way this story is told that sets it apart.
  Several reviewers claim that there is nothing positive in this book.  Not true.  These children are very smart, and they use their intelligence to overcome (sort of) the obstacles they face.  There is a lot of emphasis here on education and reading.  There is also a lot of emphasis on family.  The children clearly care about each other, and go to great lengths to protect each other.
  At one point, the evil guardian does slap one of the children.  And the guardian's nasty friends do make comments about the oldest girl's looks.  Contrary to some comments in other reviews, these incidents are not handled in a graphic way.
  If your child is (or you are) hyper-sensitive, or very easily frightened, this may not be the best book for either of you.  If your child is (or you are) intelligent and imaginative, you'll have a great time with this book.

author: CeLestine PeRez
title: A serie that infulenced my life
content:
Celestine Juquiana Perez

8/14/06 Period 5 Ms. Salinas

Olympian High School

The Baudelaire children, Violet, Klaus and Sunny. All are young, smart and good children. They live in a HUGE mansion and are really rich with anything they can ask for. So...everything is going to be perfect and happy in the future right? WRONG! Everything suddenly takes a U-turn, in a direction the Baudelaire's would never expect. Their mansion burns down, along with their loving parents. So Violet, Klaus and Sunny face a new adventure, an adventure of unpleasant hardships, with moving around to new "parents", encountering Count Olaf and his henchmen, and trying to stay alive with the rumours about the Baudelaires.

  This serie was the first series I have ever started. This series influenced me because it showed me perserverance. It showed me to never give up when the going gets tough. This series also let me have a habit of reading and curiosity. Having to always wonder what's going to happen in the book. Before I read this series, I thought it was going to be another boring and long story. But I was wrong. After I was done with the first three books...I couldn't stop. Learning new words, having a great imagination and having a love for reading. This series tells me all people have to perservere, because if you quit, you'll be lost in this crowded world of temtation. I also learned that we should not also worry about our self, but to worry about those that care for you. Help them in their time of need, as they did to you. And I learned that reading is fun. The style of this book is Adventurous and Humourous. I recommend this series to all. Have FUN! -Celestine Perez

He helps and challenges the reader with his style of writing.  Be glad it is one in a series of many!

author: Mars Velvet
title: WARNING:  DON'T READ THIS REVIEW
content:
If you have begun to read this review then it is not too late to scroll down, or go play a funny game on the net, or pick up a book about happy go lucky children.

For the book I review, Lemony Snicket's Seies of Unfortunate Events": 'The Bad Begining' is neither funny or happy or lucky.  This is a case account of the Baudelaire children:  Violet the ingenious inventer.  Klaus the scholarly reader.  And Sunny the baby who likes to bite things.  The account tells of the tragic demise of their parents who died in a fire which burned down their home.  And that's just chapter one.  Follow them as they try to escape the clutches of Count Olaf who wants their fortune left by their parents.  He will take this at any risk or cost.  A strange comic assassin with a tattoo on his ankle in the shape of an eye.  Count Olaf is truly a hateful person and should not have been put in charge of these orphans.

This volume of the series deals with mysterious fires, loss of life, secrets about a strange symbol, a deadly money hungry guardian, italian dinner, a misguided Judge, and a grappling hook.

Snicket has dedicated himself to tell the true story of the Baudelaire children.  But of course you have the option to never read this book which some people have called "mysterious", "enthralling" and a "outright lie".

author: E. A. Solinas
title: Why is this book so charming?
content:
Okay, I thought that a book about bad things that happen to a few young children couldn't possibly be good. It couldn't possibly be interesting. And it DEFINITELY wouldn't be enjoyable.
Boy am I an idiot.
The  Baudelaire children are a trio of orphans who lose their parents early in  the book, and end up being shifted to the miserly accomodations of their  Uncle Olaf, a thoroughly despicable character who comes after Saruman and  the White Witch for hateability. He wants their money, which they are not  allowed to have yet, and treats them horribly.
The characters, except the  Baudelaire children, Violet, Klaus, and Sunny, have very little character  development but somehow end up being fully believable and playing on your  emotions precisely how the writer intended. The writing style is nothing to  write home about, yet manages to be witty and descriptive--I could  practically see the events being talked about, and the characters as  well.
In a word, this book has the quality of being a wondrous story  without overdoing the detail and things like that.
Does it have a happy  ending? You can find the answer at the very first page. This is a dark  story, dark but excellent. If your children want a happily-ever-after  story, I would advise not having them read this--it will only depress them.  But if your children are not disturbed by a more realistic story, then they  will love this.

author: Toni Masters
title: And they NEVER did live happily ever after
content: Don't want another boring fairy-tale with a happily, ever after ending?This is the book for you!The bad beginning is the first of eleven equally unfortunate books about the lives of the Baudelaire children.In this book, at the very start, the three children learn the horrible news that their parents had died in an invincible fire.They are packed away into the car of their guardian, Mr Poe and are then taken to the mansion of the evil Count Olaf, all the Baudelaire know about Count Olaf is that he is greedy for their family fortune and are put into misery as they clean Olaf's mansion and cook for his guests.He also says that he wants to get together with them and start rehearsing for a play called the marvelous marriage.The children are confused and wonder why such an evil person like count would want to create a play.In this particular play, Count Olaf is meant to marry Violet Baudelare as a marriage would go, but this time it isn't a play it's for real.Get ready to see a baby hanging from a tower, a man with hooks for hands and a beautiful young bride.I won't tell you anymore but i'll give you one clue, there is no happily ever after!

author: Michael S. Waren
title: Unfortunate Bad Beginning's an Excellent place to Start
content:
In the fun-filled first novel of the series the Baudelarie children (Violet, 14, an inventor, Klaus, 12, an inquisitive reader and scholar, and Sunny, a spunky biting infant ), are orphaned by a "mysterious fire" only to be taken in by the disastrous Count Olaf who is more interested in the Baudelaire fortune than the children.  Olaf unleashes a terrible plan to marry Violet the oldest of three children by using his acting troupe and by presenting a play.  Olaf of course plans to inherit the fortune and the three children must use their wits and skills to stop him.  Will Olaf's plan be exposed before it is too late?

As a reader I am anxious to read the other books in the series as usual with this style of exceptional literature present situations are not always as they appear to be.

author: Christine E. Wagner
title: Book Review by Derek R.
content:
Do you think your life is bad?  If you do, you haven't even begun to feel what it's like to have a miserable and unfortunate events in life like the Baudelaires are having.  In Lemony Snicket's first book, The Bad Beginning, the adventure begins.  This is a fantastic book!
 The Baudelaires were once a family with no worries until a day when the Baudelaire children were at the beach and a mysterious fire destroyed their house and killed their parents.  They were assigned to other people that were close to their parents, but one person, the very first one, was a treacherous man.  His name was Count Olaf.  He figure out that the Baudelaire fortune was open and he tried to steal it.  As many times as he has tried to steal the fortune, the Baudelaire children always end up finding a way to stop him from stealing it.  Also, Count Olaf has a troupe that follows him around, and they do whatever he says, because if they don't listen to him, they don't get any part of the Baudelaire fortune.
 So read about the Baudelaires and their unfortunate events and encounters with Count Olaf and his troupe as they try to steal the Baudelaire fortune. If you don't you might never know what a miserable and unfortunate event life is like, and you'll be reminded of this story over and over until you are so miserable that you begin a story just like this one.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Loved it
content: We are triplets in 5th grade and loved reading this together.  We can't wait to start the second book of the series.

author: FloB
title: Very Entertaining!
content:
I purchased books 1-5 on audio tape to listen to with my children while driving in the car.  My how time flys when you are hearing about the perils of the Baudelaire children.  I notice traffic doesn't bother me half as much while I am listening to these stories. Somethings in life could be much worse than sitting in bumper to bumper traffic.
My children enjoy the stories so much that they don't just want to listen in the car anymore.  Every night before they go to bed we listen to about an hour of the tape.
Also, I think my children appreciate me more after they see what a hard life these children have.
I would recommend these stories for older children (older then 7). Younger or overly sensitive children might get scared or become upset by some of the things that happen.

author: Cumulonimbus Harpe
title: Gigantically Great!
content: The Bad Beginning is a good book, however, if you like stories about children who go on magnificent adventures and defeat evil villans, this book is not for you. But if you like stories about three orphans who have lost there parents in a fire and must now go live with an evil distant relative named Count Olaf who makes them do back-braking chores and has them all sleep in a room with one small bed. A story in which the orphans must cook dinner for a evil theater troop while being scolded by Count Olaf, who strikes an orphan in the face for standing up for himself and his baby sister. If you enjoy all those miserable things, you just might enjoy this book.

author: Arjun Bamzai
title: A Good Beginning
content:
I look forward to recommending this scary little book to many of my pediatric patients. It is not for the faint of heart, but my patients are usually a great deal less faint of heart than I am. Ask them and they will tell you so.
Lemony Snicket -- for that is what the author calls himself -- is sneaky. The plot twists, as expected, but unexpectedly. The atmosphere changes suddenly from horror to humor, and just as suddenly back to horror. Best of all, from my possibly pedantic perspective, the author educates his young readers, but without losing their interest by appearing to educate them. For example, words likely to be unfamiliar to preteens are accompanied by hilarious but accurate definitions.
After I wrote this review, I was dismayed to see Lemony Snicket's (real) name on an offensive "antiwar" petition (published in the New York Times and paid for by an organization called Not In Our Name). I cannot condone Daniel Handler's political views, but my enthusiasm for Lemony Snicket as a children's author is undiminished.
Arjun Bamzai

author: Jessica Bradley Barnes
title: Great children's book!
content:
I enjoyed rereading this book!  Rereading a book that you read when you are a child is like visiting a friend that you have not seen in a few years.  When I see my friends from high school that I have not talked to in three of four years, I am excited to see them, but I hope that we will be able to get along like we did in high school now that we have both changed some.  When I picked up this book, I was really excited, but I was also nervous.  What if this book was not as good as I remembered it to be and that great memory that I had was tarnished by rereading the book?

This book lived up to those extremely high expectations that I had from reading the book when I was a child.  Lemony Snicket's writing style is cynical, yet completely hilarious.  He has a subtle humor that is difficult to get used to at first, but I quickly remembered my love for it.  After I had begun reading the book again, I remembered parts of the plot, but I could not wait to read the ending.  I am glad that I reread this book.

I believe that this book would be great for children who want to read their first chapter book.  Although some of the vocabulary is advanced, the author has a great way of introducing new words to children by defining them, but not making the child feel uneducated.

author: Annabelle
title: The First Lemony Snicket book
content: I like The Bad Beginning (A Series of Unfortunate Events #1) by Lemony Snicket. It's sad that Klaus, Sunny, and Violet lose their parents in a fire.

author: Johannes
title: A Great Beginning
content: Daniel Handler aka Lemony Snicket really hit his stride in the third and fourth book of his darkly hilarious series, but the ingredients are all already in place at "THE BAD BEGINNING". These books are for smart and different children, they're basically one long starter course in irony. Where Harry Potter readers are lured into a fantasy world that is sadly void of sarcasm, the Baudelaire orphans go through one scene after another that prepares their followers for early hipsterdom. Complicated words? Bring them on. Grotesquely evil villains? Don't mind if I do! These books breathe the spirit of Edward Gorey drawings, Tom Waits songs and Tim Burton movies, all the while maintaining their very own, deliciously dark sense of wonder. If your child can't get excited about Pokémon, asks a few too many inquisitive questions and won't wear those adorable pink outfits, you have a potential Snicket-fan on your hands. Highly recommended, by the way: The genius audio versions read by Tim Curry.

author: Luz victoria
title: The bad begining
content: This is the kind of books you can not drop, you need to continue reading, because it cough you until you get to the end.

author: Sara Bass
title: Very Funny, Not Scary
content: ... I am and avid reader and read everything from Sweet Valley to Harry Potter to Animorphs (and everything in the middle). I purchased this book for summer reading, after reading the great reviews here. I was 10 then, the same age as K.Weill's son. The books are not scary, believe me. This book ilustrates some of the most tragic things in the world, yet I was not scared, as it is ilustrated in the funniest way possible. You can't help yourself cracking up in the middle. Anyway, that's my two cents.

author: hinkgen
title: Reviews by Real Kids
content:
(Matthew B.)
In my opinion, the Bad Beginning is a very good book so you should really read it.  But, it also is not a very happy book, it's sometimes scary.  If you're looking for it, it's written by Lemony Snicket.

One reason I like it is because the characters are pretty interesting.  There's Klaus who likes to read, Violet who likes to invent things, Sunny who likes to bite things, and Count Olaf who is always trying to get at the Baudelaire fortune.  Now do you see why I think the characters are so interesting?  They all have a good action to them.

Another reason it's a good book is because it's full of adventure.  The orphans are always trying to get away from their evil Count Olaf and they also try to get out of Count Olaf's play where Violet has to marry him.

Because of those reasons, this is a 3rd - 5th grade children's book.  Thanks Lemony Snicket, this book earns 4.5 stars!

(Lily L.)

I find the book the Bad Beginning very interesting.  I hope you will be as interested in the book as me soon.

One reason I find this book interesting is because of all the settings.  There are about four very interesting places the orphans visit in this book.  They are Count Olaf's house, Justice Strauss' house, the stage they perform on, and Mr. Poe's house.  Justice Strauss is their rich neighbor that makes the book a TINY bit better.  Count Olaf is a mean and rude guy, and does not look like a human being.  There are many interesting things happening in those places.

Another reason I like this book is because of the bad stuff that happens.  I LOVE books that have bad things happening.  I think you would too because INTERESTING bad stuff happens.  For example, Count Olaf, their relative, wants to live with the Baudelaire children not because he likes them, but because he wants their money.  The children are now orphans because in the first two pages their parents died.  They have a terrible life.

This book is made for people who love books WITHOUT a happy ending.  II think this is an awesome book, you should try reading it, enjoy!

author: L. B. Welsh
title: Excellent for Road Trips
content: We purchased this to listen to in the car on a recent road trip, and even though we already have the printed book and the movie, the kids were so focused on the story that they never argued or whined once! Tim Curry is magnificent as always, presenting each character with a distinctive voice and personality, and gave a new level of entertainment to a story we were already familiar with. I recommend this audiobook highly.

author: Adri
title: A great beginning to an excellent series
content: the bad beginning is everything a person could want in a book.mystery,suspense,misery,humour and reverse psychology.this book is excellent!i have only read the first three in the series and am gettin the rest for xmas.this series is depressing but there is humour added in which makes it so unique!try the series ,and if you don't thats ur problem,cause ur missin out on somthin not to be missed!

author: brityank
title: My eight, twelve and thirteen year old girls LOVED this book
content: My eight year old daughter has always said you always know what's going to happen in the end of every story, the main character will always have a happy ending, etc., so she has loved every minute of this book. I read it  out loud in the melodramatica tones the book deserves, and it was one of  our most enjoyable family read alouds ever. Obviously you have to take it  all tongue in cheek, as it is meant to be. I think it's a marvelous idea,  and hope the series goes on a while. At the end, where it says, "if  you like a happy ending, stop reading now...." I took a vote and all  three of my girls said, "READ ON!"ÿ

author: Kindle Customer
title: We're the fortunate ones...
content: ...to be able to read these delightful books! Though I was a bit apprehensive at first, reading the Unfortunate Events series has proved to be a truly entertaining adventure. The books are extremely clever, witty and fun, despite their somewhat unhappy subject matter. They succeed in being cute without crossing over to sappiness. I don't find the stories depressing, and though you do pity the Baudelaires, it's fun to side with them and find out what mess they'll next be presented with. I also think they make you examine and feel better about your own life, because no matter how awful your life may seem at times, it cannot be as bad as the life of a Baudelaire sibling!

title: Childhood memories
content: I love love all the books in the series. I'm 25 and I remember reading them as a kid. Gosh,  that seems like it was ages ago. And I have to say I still enjoy them now. The book is about sibling loyalty and love. A strong bond that can never be broken. Trials and tribulations. It's a great read.

content: Great book at a great price.  Nice to be able to introduce my daughter to Lemony Snicket at such an affordable price.  We haven't read the book yet so can't review but our niece and nephew read them and love the series.  My kids tend to like darker things...like Tim Burton movies and creepy stuff, so I think they will enjoy the dark and fantastical air of this series.

content: Read this with my 3rd and 4th grade kids. They loved it and are already begging for the second one.

author: Joan McMillin
title: Very Good Tale of An Unfortunate Family...
content: I read this book in about a day and enjoyed it thourghly.  Lemony Snicket, an unknown author to me before now, captures the reader's mind with a great plot and good story.  If you like happy endings, you'd be better off not  reading this book, for it has no happy ending, no happy beginning, and few  happy things in the middle.  Although it was an unhappy ending, it came  me wondering, and the same day I ordered The Reptile Room, The Wide Window,  The Miserable Mill, and preordered The Austere Acadamy.

author: Tamara
title: Re-reading as an adult
content: I loved these when I was young but never got a chance to finish the series because my interests changed. I am thrilled to find them just as wonderful. An easy quick fun read!

author: Yvonne
title: Surprised my kid liked it
content: My 10 yr old daughter had no interest in this series until she read book 1 as a school reading group assignment. Afterwards she was hooked. She usually enjoys books such as "Judy Moody", "Charlotte's Web", Fairy of the Realm, Harry Potter, and anything by Roald Dahl.  Yes it's true this story is about orphans whose lives are full of misery and despair so probably too creepy for kids under 9. My daughter enjoyed the humor, the suspense, the kids' intelligence and self reliance. She said some parts were a little scary but overall were mostly just suspenseful.  She is now on book #4 since each book only takes about a weekend to finish. Adults who are interested should know the book is written for children in that almost every little thing is explained which could get monotonous.

author: Amazon Customer
title: AMAZING!  A must read!
content: This is an excellent book for all ages.  I highly recommend this books for new readers looking for something interesting to read.  I have read the entire series several times, and it is no waste of time.  You will instantly be hooked and will have to read the entire series.  There is now a Netflix television show based on these novels, including a movie.  The pictures make the book even better for all readers alike.  I HIGHLY recommend reading this book.

author: ESQ
title: Hilarious
content: I believe Snicket is indeed giving Rowling a run for her money! This book is truly the work of a highly intelligent and highly comical individual.  Far from being evil or dangerous for kids, the book is inventive engaging, and happens to be a real page turner.  The characters are far from flat and invoke sympathy or disgust.  The children are loveable, especially Sunny, the biting baby.  Sprinkled throughout the book are opportunities for children to not only witness an interesting story, but also opportunities to add new words to their vocabularies.  Add to this the fact that the book s are not overly dense and long and you have the receipe for the perfect children's book.  Important: This book can also be emjoyed immensely by adults.

author: Michelle C. Hagerman
title: A tragic story, but an excellent read!
content: I read this book, because my daughter selected it for a school assignment.  To my surprise, the story was quite interesting and moving, which kept my interests peaked and my pages turning.  The events that occurred within the story were definitely unfortunate, but this book review is quite the opposite.  I look forward to discussing the contents of this book with my daughter and reading the next installment of this ever unfolding drama that I would recommend to anyone who enjoys good literature.

author: Minelly
title: The Bad Beginning
content:
The Book I choose to read was The Bad Beginning by Lemony Snicket. It was the first book of the series, A Series of Unfortunate Events. I thought it was a very interesting book to read.

  The book is about three Baudelaire children and their hardships after their parents' tragic death. Violet is the oldest of the children and she's very good at coming up with new inventions that will help them save the day. Klaus is the middle child of them three and loves to go to libraries and read books. He is also very smart. Sunny is the youngest and is the baby out of the children. Sunny loves to bite anything with her shard little teeth. Violet, Klaus, and Sunny start out having a wonderfull, happy, and rich life,until their parents die in a mysterious fire. Though their parents left them a large fortune, the Baudelaire's can't have a penny of it untill fourteen year old Violet comes of age. This means that the children have to live with a relative for the next four years. The Baudelaire's are packed off to live with Count Olaf. Count Olaf only cares about the Baudelaire's fortune, and his distingusting scheme to get his hands on it will make you very sad. But the Baudelaire children fight back using their unique and individual talents. When the children find out Count Olaf's evil plan, they try everything to stop him before it's too late.

  I really enjoyed reading The Bad Beginning by Lemony Snicket. It is a very interesting book to read. The events' leading to the climax and the climax was very detailed. I also liked the character's personalities because they were very easy to relate to. One of my favorite characters was Sunny, the baby. I liked how the author included the baby into the conversations and while the characters were talking Sunny would cut in with baby gibberish, I would really recommend this book to anyone. It is very detailed and interesting.

author: Ellie
title: Bad Luck
content: This is a gripping novel about three children who's parents die and thet have to go and stay with a distant relative.This is a bad move because the only thing this horrid man cares about is the fortune the baudelaires recieve.He goes to desparate measuress such as trying to marry one of them, just to recieve this money.This sort of story line carries on in different ways in the whole series!
